repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: terminal mode cursor refresh logic has too many edge cases where it
fails when events change curbuf.

Solution: change the logic. Introduce cursor_visible to TerminalState to more
reliably track if terminal mode has changed busy. Move visibility handling to
refresh_cursor and move its call in refresh_terminal to terminal_check to avoid
temporarily changed curbufs from influencing cursor state.

This has the effect of "debouncing" shape/visibility updates to once per
terminal state tick (with the final attributes taking effect, as expected). I
think this is OK, but as a result it may also be warranted to update when
redrawing during the same state tick (e.g: from events executing :redraw); this
can be added later, if wanted.

Also move previous tests to a more appropriate place.

comment_data.body: Can you leave a doc comment here describing this field? With both this field and `cursor.visible` in the `Terminal` struct having clarity on what each field does will be useful.

> refresh_ functions assume the terminal buffer is current

Worth adding an `assert`?
Since `refresh_cursor` is no longer called in `refresh_terminal` and is only called in `terminal_check`, would it make sense to move/combine this function into `terminal_check_cursor`?

Only applies to `refresh_screen` and `refresh_scrollback` these days (due to the use of curbuf'd memline and buffer update functions). The former already has an assert; I'll add one for the latter. :+1:

Reason was that `terminal_check_cursor` may be called more often (my other fixes do this, some without access to the `TerminalState`); `refresh_cursor` seemed adequate enough before a UI flush.

That said, `refresh_cursor` is also called in `terminal_enter` still, which I suppose isn't strictly necessary anymore though.

Want to make sure I understand: would it be correct to say that this field represents the _actual_ visibility of the cursor, while the `cursor.visible` field in `Terminal` represents whether the cursor _should_ be visible for that particular terminal?
yup that's correct (and a better way of explaining it than I have lmao)
What is the relation to `cursor.visible`, which still exists?

`cursor.visible` is whether the terminal wants the cursor to be shown, `cursor_visible` is whether it is actually currently being shown by the terminal mode (whether or not terminal mode has actually incremented `busy` already).

comment_regular_data.body: Moving the other fixes back out of this PR so the cursor vis fix can be merged asap with the release looming (as it's arguably the most user-facing issue :innocent:)

repo.description: [Contribution Fork] Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(terminal): improve cursor refresh handling
